text:
The time-weighted rate of return measures compound growth. It is the rate at which $1
compounds over a specified performance horizon.
If funds are added to a portfolio just before a period of poor performance, the moneyweighted return will be lower than the time-weighted return. If funds are added just
prior to a period of high returns, the money-weighted return will be higher than the
time-weighted return.
The time-weighted return is the preferred measure of a manager's ability to select
investments. If the manager controls the money flows into and out of an account, the
money-weighted return is the more appropriate performance measure.
